required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Ureteral Stents Length and Location on Related Symptom
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Ureteral Stents Length and Location on Related Symptom

lead_sponsor.agency: Taipei Medical University Shuang Ho Hospital

clinical_study.source: Taipei Medical University Shuang Ho Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: This is a prospective randomized clinical trial, evaluating the effect of the intra-ureteral placement of the stent's distal end versus the conventional stent placement on the postoperative LUTS and pain.

detailed_description.textblock: Intravesical stent mass has been considered to cause stent-related symptoms, such as LUTS and pain. The current study hypothesized that the total intra-ureteral placement of the stent's distal end could decrease postoperative LUTS and pain. We proposed a prospective randomized trials, investigating the effect of intra-ureteral stent placement versus conventional stent placement. The primary end point was postoperative LUTS. The secondary end points were postoperative pain and quality of life. We used USSQ questionnaire as the assessing tool.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Arm 1: Intra-ureteral placement of double-J stent Arm 2: Conventional placement of double-J stent
study_design_info.masking_description: Patients were not informed the allocation until the stent was removed.

primary_outcome.measure: Lower urinary tract symptom after placement of D-J stent
primary_outcome.description: The symptoms are evaluated by a complete USSQ (Ureteral Stent Symptom Questionnaire) urinary index. The minimum and maximum values are 11 and 53, and the higher scores mean a worse outcome

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain after placement of D-J stent
secondary_outcome.description: The symptoms are evaluated by a complete USSQ (Ureteral Stent Symptom Questionnaire) pain index and general health index. The minimum and maximum values of the body pain index are 2 and 43. The minimum and maximum values of the general health index are 4 and 28. The higher scores of both mean a worse outcome.

arm_group.arm_group_label: The intraureteral placement of distal end of ureteral stent
arm_group.description: Patients randomized to this group received 5-16/5-18 D-J stent with intraureteral placement of the distal end

arm_group.arm_group_label: The conventional placement of the distal end of ureteral stent
arm_group.description: Patients randomized to this group received 5-22/5-24 D-J stent with bladder placement of the distal end

intervention.description: Boston Scientific Polaris™ Ultra Ureteral Stent
intervention.arm_group_label: The intraureteral placement of distal end of ureteral stent

intervention.description: Boston Scientific Polaris™ Ultra Ureteral Stent
intervention.arm_group_label: The conventional placement of the distal end of ureteral stent

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of unilateral ureteral stone
- Plan to undergo unilateral URS lithotripsy
- Adult patients (>18 years old)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pre-stented cases
- Distal ureteral stones
- Preoperative urinary tract infection
- With medications known to influence stent-related symptoms, including alpha-blockers, antimuscarinics, beta3-agonist
- Pregnancy
- Other procedures required during the procedure of lithotripsy
- A stent was expected to be indwelled for more than 10 days (ureteral stricture, ureteral tumors/polyps, ureteral trauma, and a large amount of stone fragments)

overall_official.affiliation: Shuang Ho Hospital Taipei Medical University

facility.name: Shuang Ho Hospital Taipei Medical University

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Taipei Medical University Shuang Ho Hospital
